content: The "Homeowners' Assistance Act of 2007" allows tax-favored withdrawals from retirement plans for mortgage relief. The "Homeowners' Assistance Act of 2007" allows tax-favored withdrawals from retirement plans for mortgage relief. Section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts qualified mortgage relief distributions from penalties. There is a $25,000 limit on the total amount of qualified mortgage relief distributions an individual can receive in a taxable year. The plan allows tax-favored withdrawals for mortgage relief without penalty under Section 72(t) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A $25,000 limit applies to total distributions per individual in a taxable year. Contributions can be made within 5 years of receiving a qualified mortgage relief distribution. The individual can make contributions to an eligible retirement plan after receiving a distribution for mortgage relief without penalty. Repayments of distributions from eligible retirement plans other than IRAs are also allowed under certain conditions. The individual can contribute to an eligible retirement plan after receiving a distribution for mortgage relief without penalty. Repayments for distributions from IRAs are treated as direct transfers within 60 days. The term "qualified mortgage relief distribution" refers to any distribution from an eligible retirement plan made between the enactment of the Act and January 1, 2010, if it occurs within a 90-day period of an interest rate increase on the loan. The term "qualified mortgage relief distribution" applies to distributions from eligible retirement plans between the Act's enactment and January 1, 2010, under specific income and residence conditions. Eligible retirement plans are defined by section 402(c)(8)(B) of the tax code. The term "principal residence" has the same meaning as in section 121 of the Internal Revenue Code. Qualified mortgage relief distributions require income inclusion spread over a 5-year period, with special rules applying. Exemptions exist for trustee to trustee transfers and withholding rules. Qualified mortgage relief distributions are not considered eligible rollover distributions for tax purposes. Such distributions are treated as meeting plan distribution requirements under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Plan amendments related to these distributions must be operated in accordance with the plan terms during a specified period. The subsection applies to plan or annuity contract amendments made in accordance with specific regulations by the Secretary of the Treasury or the Secretary of Labor. It must be done by the last day of the first plan year starting on or after January 1, 2010, or a later date set by the Treasury Secretary. For governmental plans, as defined in the Internal Revenue Code, these rules apply. Section 414(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that certain conditions must be met for plan or contract amendments, with specific regulations set by the Treasury or Labor Secretary. The subsection does not apply to any amendment unless certain conditions are met within a specified period. Section 414(d) of the Internal Revenue Code sets conditions for plan or contract amendments, with regulations by the Treasury or Labor Secretary. The plan or contract operates as if the amendment is in effect, applying retroactively for the specified period.
